clusters.title: What you need to know about Bolsonaro's coup prison sentence

items.title: What you need to know about Bolsonaro's coup prison sentence
items.standfirst: The former president of Brazil has been sentenced to 27 years in prison after being found guilty for plotting a military coup.
items.content: The former president of Brazil has been sentenced to 27 years in prison after being found guilty for plotting a military coup.

items.title: Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in prison for plotting Brazil coup
items.standfirst: The former president has been found guilty of trying to mount coup to cling to power after he lost the election.
items.content: The former president has been found guilty of trying to mount coup to cling to power after he lost the election.

items.title: Brazil's Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years after being convicted of coup attempt
items.standfirst: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, the far-right politician who governed Brazil between 2019 and 2022, was found guilty on five counts.
items.content: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, the far-right politician who governed Brazil between 2019 and 2022, was found guilty on five counts.

items.title: Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years for plotting military coup in Brazil
items.standfirst: Former president sought to ‘annihilate’ country’s democracy after losing 2022 electionExplainer: what did Bolsonaro’s trial reveal?​Brazil’s former far-right president Jair Bolsonaro ​has been sentenced to more than 27 years in prison for plotting a military coup​ and seeking to “annihilate” the South American country’s democracy.Justices Cármen Lúcia Antunes Rocha and Cristiano Zanin ruled on ​Thursday that Bolsonaro – a former paratrooper who was elected president in 2018 – was guilty of seeking to forcibly cling to power after losing the 2022 election, meaning four of the five judges involved in the trial had found Brazil’s former leader guilty. Continue reading...
items.content: Former president sought to ‘annihilate’ country’s democracy after losing 2022 electionExplainer: what did Bolsonaro’s trial reveal?​Brazil’s former far-right president Jair Bolsonaro ​has been sentenced to more than 27 years in prison for plotting a military coup​ and seeking to “annihilate” the South American country’s democracy.Justices Cármen Lúcia Antunes Rocha and Cristiano Zanin ruled on ​Thursday that Bolsonaro – a former paratrooper who was elected president in 2018 – was guilty of seeking to forcibly cling to power after losing the 2022 election, meaning four of the five judges involved in the trial had found Brazil’s former leader guilty. Continue reading...

items.title: Brazil Supreme Court sentences Bolsonaro to 27 years over coup plot
items.standfirst: Sentence comes shortly after a majority of justices voted to convict the former Brazilian leader on five charges.
items.content: Sentence comes shortly after a majority of justices voted to convict the former Brazilian leader on five charges.

items.title: Brazil's ex-President Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years for coup plot
items.standfirst: A historic conviction: Brazil's Supreme Court delivers a majority vote to convict former President Jair Bolsonaro over a plot to overthrow the government.
items.content: A historic conviction: Brazil's Supreme Court delivers a majority vote to convict former President Jair Bolsonaro over a plot to overthrow the government.(Image credit: Mateus Bonomi)

items.title: What did Jair Bolsonaro’s trial reveal about an attempted coup in Brazil?
items.standfirst: Far-right ex-president was found to have led a ‘criminal organisation’ to try to stay in powerBolsonaro found guilty of plotting military coupBrazil’s supreme court has made Jair Bolsonaro the first former president in the country’s history to be convicted for attempting a coup.The 70-year-old far-right leader claims he is the victim of political persecution, but three out of five judges concluded on Thursday that it was sufficiently proven that Bolsonaro and his close allies attempted to overturn the 2022 election, which he lost to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Continue reading...
items.content: Far-right ex-president was found to have led a ‘criminal organisation’ to try to stay in powerBolsonaro found guilty of plotting military coupBrazil’s supreme court has made Jair Bolsonaro the first former president in the country’s history to be convicted for attempting a coup.The 70-year-old far-right leader claims he is the victim of political persecution, but three out of five judges concluded on Thursday that it was sufficiently proven that Bolsonaro and his close allies attempted to overturn the 2022 election, which he lost to Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. Continue reading...

items.title: Updates: Brazil Supreme Court votes to convict Bolsonaro on all charges
items.standfirst: Bolsonaro set to be sentenced on charges related to planning coup after three justices vote to convict.
items.content: Bolsonaro set to be sentenced on charges related to planning coup after three justices vote to convict.

items.title: Brazil's ex-president sentenced to 27 years in jail - as Trump warns conviction is 'very bad' for country
items.standfirst: Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to 27 years and three months in prison for attempting a coup to stay in power after his 2022 election defeat.
items.content: Brazil's former president Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to 27 years and three months in prison for attempting a coup to stay in power after his 2022 election defeat.

ai_summary: Former Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro was sentenced to 27 years in prison.
He was found guilty of plotting a military coup after losing the 2022 election.
The Supreme Court convicted Bolsonaro on five charges related to the plot.
The court determined Bolsonaro sought to undermine Brazil's democracy.
The sentence was decided by a majority vote of the justices involved.

items.title: Prince Harry makes surprise visit to Ukraine pledging support for thousands injured in war
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Prince and team from his Invictus Games Foundation were invited to Kyiv and will detail new initiatives to support woundedPrince Harry has made a surprise visit to Kyiv after an invitation from the Ukrainian government, saying he wanted to do “everything possible” to help the recovery of the thousands of military personnel who have been seriously injured in the three-year war against Russia.During the trip to the Ukrainian capital, he and a team from his Invictus Games Foundation are set to detail new initiatives to support the rehabilitation of the wounded, with the eventual aim of providing help to all areas of the country. clusters.title: OpenAI and Microsoft reach tentative deal to revise partnership
clusters.neutral_headline: OpenAI and Microsoft Reach Tentative Deal to Revise Partnership

items.title: OpenAI and Microsoft reach tentative deal to revise partnership
OpenAI and Microsoft sketch out deal to unlock for-profit restructuring
items.standfirst: Nonbinding term marks progress in talks to enable ChatGPT maker’s eventual IPO
items.content: Nonbinding term marks progress in talks to enable ChatGPT maker’s eventual IPO

items.title: OpenAI and Microsoft sign preliminary deal to revise partnership terms
items.standfirst: Companies work to finalize terms as OpenAI pursues for-profit restructuring.
items.content: On Thursday, OpenAI and Microsoft announced they have signed a non-binding agreement to revise their partnership, marking the latest development in a relationship that has grown increasingly complex as both companies compete for customers in the AI market and seek new partnerships for growing infrastructure needs. "Microsoft and OpenAI have signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MOU) for the next phase of our partnership," the companies wrote in a joint statement. "We are actively working to finalize contractual terms in a definitive agreement. Together, we remain focused on delivering the best AI tools for everyone, grounded in our shared commitment to safety." The announcement comes as OpenAI seeks to restructure from a nonprofit to a for-profit entity, a transition that requires Microsoft's approval, as the company is OpenAI's largest investor with more than $13 billion committed since 2019.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: OpenAI and Microsoft reached a preliminary deal to revise their partnership.
The deal aims to unlock for-profit restructuring for OpenAI.
The companies are working to finalize the terms of the agreement.
The agreement is a nonbinding term marking progress in talks.
OpenAI is pursuing a for-profit restructuring of its operations.
